citation.article-title: Salicola marasensis gen. nov., sp. nov., an extremely halophilic bacterium isolated from the Maras solar salterns in Peru
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Salicola (Sa.li′co.la. L. n. sal, salis salt, salt water, brine; L. masc. suff. -cola from L. n. incola an inhabitant; N.L. masc. n. Salicola an inhabitant of brine).
Rod-shaped bacteria, motile by means of single polar flagella.
Gram-negative, strictly aerobic, heterotrophic, oxidase-, catalase-, urease-, phenylalanine decarboxylase-, β-galactosidase- and gelatinase-positive and able to use carbohydrates.
Inhabitants of highly saline habitats such as salt lakes, saltern ponds and salt flats; in general, optimum growth occurs at salt concentrations above 14 % (w/v).
Major fatty acids of the genus are C12 : 0 3-OH, C16 : 0, C18 : 1ω9c and C18 : 0 10-methyl.
The latter fatty acid distinguishes Salicola species from the most closely related genera.
The DNA G+C content of members of the genus ranges between 61.3 and 61.9 mol%.
The type species of the genus is Salicola marasensis.
